articles.headline: Site-Hopping for Holiday Savings
articles.snippet: Instead of going straight to a retailer, online shoppers may do better by choosing another entrance to that retailer’s Web site.
articles.abstract: Instead of going straight to a retailer, online shoppers may do better by choosing another entrance to that retailer’s Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember the old game show where contestants could choose which door was hiding the best prize? A variation of that is happening online this holiday shopping season.

articles.headline: Kazakh Bank Lost Billions in Western Investments
articles.snippet: Several of the world’s largest banks funneled loans to Bank Turalem of Kazakhstan, but many of these loans have failed, forcing steep write-offs.
articles.abstract: Several of the world’s largest banks funneled loans to Bank Turalem of Kazakhstan, but many of these loans have failed, forcing steep write-offs.

articles.headline: Crashers Met Obama; Secret Service Apologizes
articles.snippet: The disclosure that a celebrity- seeking couple who sneaked into a state dinner came face to face with the president underscored the seriousness of the security breach.
articles.abstract: The disclosure that a celebrity- seeking couple who sneaked into a state dinner came face to face with the president underscored the seriousness of the security breach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his wife, Michelle, had a face-to-face encounter with the couple who sneaked into a state dinner at the White House this week, White House officials acknowledged on Friday. The revelation underscored the seriousness of the security breach and prompted an abject apology from the Secret Service.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: From Shadow to Limelight for a Governor’s Wife
articles.snippet: South Carolina’s first lady has reacted to her husband’s infidelity by building up herself — and her career.
articles.abstract: South Carolina’s first lady has reacted to her husband’s infidelity by building up herself — and her career.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the political standing of Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina continues to crumble, the career of his wife, Jenny Sanford, seems to be taking off.

articles.headline: Dubai Debt Woes Raise Fear of Wider Problem
articles.snippet: Dubai’s inability to repay its debt is fueling concern that other countries and institutions could be in trouble too.
articles.abstract: Dubai’s inability to repay its debt is fueling concern that other countries and institutions could be in trouble too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the many economies that gorged on debt in the boom years, Dubai stood out. In the space of a few years the emirate’s investment arm, Dubai World, racked up $59 billion in debt, borrowing to build lavish developments like a giant island shaped like a palm tree to entice celebrities like Brad Pitt, and to invest in glittery properties like the MGM Grand Casino in Las Vegas.

articles.headline: Buying, Selling and Twittering All the Way
articles.snippet: On Black Friday, retailers and their customers used the social networking site Twitter to talk to one another about bargains, problems, purchases and shopping strategies.
articles.abstract: On Black Friday, retailers and their customers used the social networking site Twitter to talk to one another about bargains, problems, purchases and shopping strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, people mailed their holiday wishes to the North Pole and hoped for a reply on Christmas Day. Nowadays they are sending their wishes into cyberspace and are apt to get a reply in minutes.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Karen Ann Cullotta

articles.headline: Afghans Offer Jobs to Taliban Rank and File if They Defect
articles.snippet: The U.S. is underwriting a program that seeks to disarm fighters and enlist tribal leaders’ support by involving them in choosing development projects where jobs are offered.
articles.abstract: The U.S. is underwriting a program that seeks to disarm fighters and enlist tribal leaders’ support by involving them in choosing development projects where jobs are offered.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  The American-backed campaign to persuade legions of Taliban gunmen to stop fighting got under way here recently, in an ornate palace filled with Afghan tribal leaders and one very large former warlord leading the way.

articles.headline: Health Care Savings Could Start in the Cafeteria
articles.snippet: A start-up company is aiming to help companies lower medical costs by offering employees healthier diets.
articles.abstract: A start-up company is aiming to help companies lower medical costs by offering employees healthier diets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Burd isn’t a doctor or a medical specialist. But he sure can talk like one.

articles.headline: Afghans Detail Detention in ‘Black Jail’ at U.S. Base
articles.snippet: A U.S. camp is holding inmates for sometimes weeks at a time, without access to the International Committee of the Red Cross, researchers and former detainees say.
articles.abstract: A U.S. camp is holding inmates for sometimes weeks at a time, without access to the International Committee of the Red Cross, researchers and former detainees say.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American military detention camp in Afghanistan is still holding inmates, sometimes for weeks at a time, without access to the International Committee of the Red Cross, according to human rights researchers and former detainees held at the site on the Bagram Air Base.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Push Mortgage Firms to Reduce More Loan Payments
articles.snippet: Only a tiny fraction of mortgages have been permanently reduced under a $75 billion program for troubled homeowners.
articles.abstract: Only a tiny fraction of mortgages have been permanently reduced under a $75 billion program for troubled homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday plans to announce a campaign to pressure mortgage companies to reduce payments for many more troubled homeowners, as evidence mounts that a $75 billion taxpayer-financed effort aimed at stemming foreclosures is foundering.

articles.headline: Get Ready for Half a Recovery
articles.snippet: Until the debt clouds disappear in the economy, small business can’t lead a rebound.
articles.abstract: Until the debt clouds disappear in the economy, small business can’t lead a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: A ROBUST economic recovery in 2010 is certainly on most investors’ wish lists as this year draws to a close. A return to prosperity would not only mean an end to our long financial nightmare, but it would also buttress a rebounding stock market, one of 2009’s few bright spots.

articles.headline: South Carolina Rift Highlights Debate Over G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Some Republicans in South Carolina are questioning the conservative bona fides of Senator Lindsey Graham.
articles.abstract: Some Republicans in South Carolina are questioning the conservative bona fides of Senator Lindsey Graham.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C.  When Senator Lindsey Graham joined forces last month with Senator John Kerry on a compromise to the climate change legislation known as cap and trade, it was the last straw for the Charleston County Republican Party.

articles.headline: Wines, With Notes of M.B.A.
articles.snippet: A wave of M.B.A.’s, bankers, chemists and others are taking over or starting wineries and infusing them with a level of business expertise usually found only at big brands.
articles.abstract: A wave of M.B.A.’s, bankers, chemists and others are taking over or starting wineries and infusing them with a level of business expertise usually found only at big brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rutherford, Calif.

articles.headline: Food Stamp Use Soars, and Stigma Fades
articles.snippet: A program once scorned as a failed welfare scheme now helps feed one in eight Americans and one in four children.
articles.abstract: A program once scorned as a failed welfare scheme now helps feed one in eight Americans and one in four children.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARTINSVILLE, Ohio  With food stamp use at record highs and climbing every month, a program once scorned as a failed welfare scheme now helps feed one in eight Americans and one in four children.
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Leader Cedes Nuclear Office
articles.snippet: President Asif Ali Zardari handed over his position in the nuclear command structure to his prime minister, in a sudden maneuver widely seen as a fresh sign of turmoil.
articles.abstract: President Asif Ali Zardari handed over his position in the nuclear command structure to his prime minister, in a sudden maneuver widely seen as a fresh sign of turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari has ceded his position in Pakistan’s nuclear command structure to his prime minister, in a sudden political maneuver widely seen as a fresh sign of turmoil on the eve of President Obama’s strategy announcement for the region.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: A Defiant Iran Vows to Build Nuclear Plants
articles.snippet: The declaration appeared intended to convince the West that Iran was prepared to move closer to bomb-grade quality, while stopping short of crossing that threshold.
articles.abstract: The declaration appeared intended to convince the West that Iran was prepared to move closer to bomb-grade quality, while stopping short of crossing that threshold.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Iran angrily refused Sunday to comply with a demand by the United Nations nuclear agency to cease work on a once-secret nuclear fuel enrichment plant, and escalated the confrontation by declaring it would construct 10 more such plants.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Open Source as a Model for Business Is Elusive
articles.snippet: European Commission reaction to Oracle’s acquisition of Sun Microsystems has stoked a tricky debate: Can open-source software live up to its populist traditions?
articles.abstract: European Commission reaction to Oracle’s acquisition of Sun Microsystems has stoked a tricky debate: Can open-source software live up to its populist traditions?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In many ways, MySQL embodies the ideals of the populist software movement known as open source, in which a program’s creator releases it to the world free of charge, and legions of volunteers contribute improvements that are also freely shared.

articles.headline: In Japan, an Odd Perch for Google: Looking Up at the Leader
articles.snippet: After missteps in Japan, Google is striving to gain ground against Yahoo and make the most of a highly connected marketplace.
articles.abstract: After missteps in Japan, Google is striving to gain ground against Yahoo and make the most of a highly connected marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  In 2001, a fledgling Internet company named Google opened its first overseas office in Japan, eager to tap a huge technology market.

articles.headline: The Fall and Rise of Media
articles.snippet: Print publishers and the writers and editors who worked for them once ruled the literary roost in New York. Now, make way for those who push pixels.
articles.abstract: Print publishers and the writers and editors who worked for them once ruled the literary roost in New York. Now, make way for those who push pixels.
articles.lead_paragraph: Historically, young women and men who sought to thrive in publishing made their way to Manhattan. Once there, they were told, they would work in marginal jobs for indifferent bosses doing mundane tasks and then one day, if they did all of that without whimper or complaint, they would magically be granted access to a gilded community, the large heaving engine of books, magazines and newspapers.

articles.headline: A Takeover Movie for Hollywood to Watch
articles.snippet: As the movie industry struggles to find its footing, the takeover of Universal Studios by Comcast may serve as a learning experience for everyone.
articles.abstract: As the movie industry struggles to find its footing, the takeover of Universal Studios by Comcast may serve as a learning experience for everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Not long ago, a first meeting between Hollywood executives and the potential new owners of their studio might have turned on Oscar prospects, this year’s ingénue or the exact dimensions of Russell Crowe’s salary.

articles.headline: Shoppers Showed Up, but Spent on Bargains
articles.snippet: About 23 million more consumers visited retail stores and Web sites over the weekend, but total spending was about the same as last year.
articles.abstract: About 23 million more consumers visited retail stores and Web sites over the weekend, but total spending was about the same as last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: More consumers flooded the nation’s stores on Thanksgiving weekend in search of bargains. But with retailers dangling rock-bottom prices and consumers only biting at less expensive merchandise like small appliances and winter clothes, the average amount spent by each shopper declined from last year.

articles.headline: Obama’s Speech on Afghanistan to Envision Exit
articles.snippet: President Obama plans to lay out a time frame for U.S. involvement in the Afghan war when he announces his decision this week to send more forces, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama plans to lay out a time frame for U.S. involvement in the Afghan war when he announces his decision this week to send more forces, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON    President Obama plans to lay out a time frame for winding down the American involvement in the war in Afghanistan when he announces his decision this week to send more forces, senior administration officials said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Arab Emirates Aim to Limit Dubai Crisis in Pledge to Banks
articles.snippet: The United Arab Emirates pledged to lend money to Dubai banks in an attempt to head off the kind of crisis of confidence that froze credit markets last year.
articles.abstract: The United Arab Emirates pledged to lend money to Dubai banks in an attempt to head off the kind of crisis of confidence that froze credit markets last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to prevent a run on its banks and stem financial turmoil that some fear could spread globally, the United Arab Emirates helped calm markets Monday by pledging to lend money to banks operating in Dubai. But the action comes amid concerns about excessive borrowing around the world.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: As Sales Vanish, Skins Stay on Alligators
articles.snippet: The peculiar relationship between hardy bayou men and Paris and New York fashion setters has soured of late.
articles.abstract: The peculiar relationship between hardy bayou men and Paris and New York fashion setters has soured of late.
articles.lead_paragraph: RACELAND, La.  After five years, Tommy Fletcher and his alligator farming business are facing irreconcilable differences.

articles.headline: Crisis Puts Focus on Dubai’s Complex Relationship With Abu Dhabi
articles.snippet: Dubai is famous as the brash, secular upstart of the emirates, and Abu Dhabi is known as the religious and conservative big brother.
articles.abstract: Dubai is famous as the brash, secular upstart of the emirates, and Abu Dhabi is known as the religious and conservative big brother.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr
